participants.participant: P. Nozipho January-Bardill, Group Executive, Corporate Affairs and MTN Group Spokesperson
Phuthuma Nhleko, Group President and Chief Executive Officer

plist.p: Good morning. Salam Aleikum. Bonjour, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to MTN Group's Interim Results Presentations for the six months ended June 2010.

I'm the executive for Group Corporate Affairs, and I'll be the program director this morning. And so my task is to extend a very warm welcome to all of you on behalf of both the Group board and the executive committee. And also to introduce our panelists, who I'm sure you're very familiar with. Mr. Phuthuma Nhleko, our Group President and CEO; Mr. Sifiso Dabengwa, on the other side, who is our Chief Operating Officer; and Mr. Nazir Patel, our Group Finance Director. And I will also try to explain the structure of the morning.

In the audience, we also welcome some of our shareholders, analysts, members of the media, and members of our board, both from MTN South Africa and the Group. And of course my colleagues at the front here in the executive team who drive the business strategy.

We'd also like to acknowledge our Senior Vice President, Mr. Christian De Faria who is here. As you know Christian used to be the VP of our WECA region. Our acting VP in the WECA region Mr. Ahmad Farroukh, and Mr. Jamal Ramadan, our VP in the MENA region, will both be watching from various webcasts in their regional bases. And so welcome to them as well.

And of course, last but not least, ladies and gentlemen, we also welcoming the audience, the management and staff of both MTN Group and MTN South Africa. And a warm greeting to the rest of our staff in the 20 other operations without whose efforts MTN would not be the success that it is. They also will be watching through various electronic media that we've set up.

The presentation will last approximately one and a half hours, and the agenda, as usual, is quite straightforward. Our Group President and CEO, Mr. Nhleko, will present the Group's strategic and operational overview. He will be followed by the Group Financial Officer, Mr. Nazir Patel, who will deliver the financials. And Phuthuma will then complete the presentations with some concluding remarks. After the presentation you will be invited to ask questions, if you have any and our staff members will give you roaming microphones to do that.

And so at this point, I'd like to invite you to please turn off your cell phones or put them on silent. And when we have completed the presentation, of course, as usual, we'd like to invite you for a little snack outside.
And so without much ado, I'd like to invite our Group President to come and present the results. Phuthuma?
Good morning, everybody. And just to echo Nozipho's welcome.

And it's really an honor always to present to you our results, and of course, to welcome all the MTNers that are on webcast. And hopefully this is a reflection of what they've been doing in the last six months. So thank you very much for the time you've made to come to MTN.
Let me begin the results by giving just the trading environment certainly as we see it. And I do think it's characterized by a number of issues.

Firstly, we do believe that, of course, there has been the financial crisis and then the economic slowdown. But we would like to believe that we are at a phase where we're starting to see some stability in that. And hopefully, it will not be a double-dip recession, as other people have predicted. But for now, we seem to have seen the worst.

We also have a scenario certainly in our footprint where there is fairly intense competition. There have been a lot of new entrants, strong entrants, which obviously brings also some other pressures. But we certainly believe that MTN is well positioned to weather that.

Thirdly, we have a increasingly tough regulatory environment. I think the regulators are flexing their muscle and showing more teeth. Again, we do believe that we are arranged as a group in a manner that allows us to anticipate and preempt certain actions. And, of course, as we penetrate into the last segments of the markets, we are seeing decline in ARPU, which is what is expected.

Most probably, the most impactful feature of these results would be the exchange rates, in the sense that we are a rand-based company, notwithstanding over 70% of our earnings in other currencies. Because of rand reporting, we do see that volatility.
So I think, by and large, that's really the environment in which we find ourselves.

From time to time, we, of course, do a review and just ensure that the fundamentals that are important – or pillars, if you like, to the vision of the Group – remain sound. And we've shown this slide I think quite consistently over a number of years, to say that the whole issue of convergence operationally, over time, is something that will be there. We need to look at. We need to continuously leverage the footprint that we have.

And, of course, this business is in many respect about intellectual capacity, so we guard that fairly jealously. And I've always believed that there is going to be consolidation in this industry. And I think we are starting to see that. I think you just need to look at the last sort of six to nine months, and you'll realize that there is consolidation, as people find out that unless you've got meaningful scale, it becomes fairly, fairly difficult to compete.

And then I think the blocks at the bottom there are really just saying you've got the pillars, the three pillars, but really what are the cornerstones? And the cornerstones are all those aspects of our business that we constantly review to ensure that we remain fairly competitive.

Another way of representing this is through what I regard as most probably six fairly important cornerstones. Given the high penetration, increased competition, fairly mature markets, the question is how do we continue to differentiate ourselves from the competition?

We certainly believe that quality of service – and I'm talking first and foremost the network service, network quality – is fairly crucial. We've invested significant amount of money over the years to improve that. And I think that is a marked difference in most of our major operations.

Distribution is certainly going to be a battleground in virtually all of the countries. Again, we've spent a great deal of time and money in this area, in South Africa and Nigeria, in particular, in recent years. We've invested a lot that has ensured that we have a fairly robust and competitive distribution network. And I think that is going to be a fairly important, telling future going forward.

Segmentation, again, we've spent a great deal of time and money with consultants and ourselves to try and have a far finer way of defining our markets, and therefore ensuring a much higher yield in various segments of the market. And this is really something that's become virtually ingrained in our budgeting process and everything else that we do.
Fourthly, experienced people. This is at all levels, but most importantly, at customer-interfacing level. We try to ensure that we improve the quality of people there.

And then the whole issue of innovation is important. MTN, not being part of the larger global groups, has to a lot of homegrown innovation. And I think there is a lot of work that's been done in this area, whether it's roaming, MobileMoney, MTN Zone, and so on. I mean all of these are internally generated products that hopefully will ensure that we are competitive.

And then last and not least, I think brand defines us in many respects. We recently spent quite an amount of time and effort and money on the FIFA World Cup. We certainly hope that helps to advance our position as a significant global brand and a brand of choice. So in short, all I'm saying is, given the stage and phase where we find ourselves in this industry, this has become central. Not to say that it wasn't important in the past, but this has become a central piece of how we're going to differentiate ourselves.

And looking at the results, the highlights, again, just to say that the big wind here is always currency. And not to sort of give our view on where the rand should be. I don't think that's our job. Suffice to say that in the last six months, we've had a very, very heavy headwind as opposed to a tailwind.

Notwithstanding that, the subs are up since December by 11.4% to almost 139 million subs. EBITDA margin is up 0.5 to 43.3. I know this is not the 45 that I've always said that we're going to try and target. But nevertheless, we think we're still moving in the right direction. Iran and South Africa contributed quite a lot to helping us push up that margin, and we'll get into that detail a little bit more.

And of course, adjusted headline earnings per share up over 20% to 438 cents. And some of those things obviously are also impacted by currency exposure and what we have done to try and mitigate that. And I think Nazir will deal with that under the financial section.

Then we have decided that MTN is now in a position to go into paying an interim dividend, effectively as a continuous policy going forward, which we haven't done in the past. And that interim dividend would be 151 cents per share.

Of course, we do have the leisure of paying that dividend because – and going on to that policy, shall I say – because of the much stronger cash flows we're now generating in the Group. And if you look at the free cash flow on a comparative period basis, it's up almost 164% to R6.8 billion.

And lastly, let me just say, I think if you just take that very wide overview of the Group, with net debts very low – I remember a few years ago we stood here after Investcom acquisition, and we said it would be brought down to – I think it was 0.4 net debt-to-EBITDA. I mean we're now down to 0.1 or 0.11. So I think at least that does say that the decisions that have been taken in the last few years as far as the capital structure have borne themselves out.

Getting more into the operational matters, nothing has changed radically as far as the split of the subscribers in a geographic sense of the word. We've always say that we would have liked to have had a third in the SEA region, a third in the MENA region, and a third in the WECA region. But of course I think with very strong performance of Nigeria and Ghana, in particular, we are getting close to 50% of our subs coming from the WECA region.

Revenue – again, because of the currency headwinds, you will see that the contribution of revenue from the operations outside South Africa has been a bit more muted compared to the same period in 2009. Of course, revenue itself on a Group-wide basis is almost flat, precisely because of the currency.

EBITDA, I think, reflects very much the same sort of pattern, notwithstanding 70% of the earnings being non-South-African or non-rand earnings. And as I indicated earlier, we're very pleased with the margin up-tick that we have seen in the last six months as a result of the strong EBITDA pick-up in South Africa and Iran.

Nigeria, of course, is now effectively the largest contributor to the Group. We have increased market share in Nigeria to 51%. The distribution reconstruction that took place a number of years ago in Nigeria, where we organized really on a regional basis, with key dealers in those areas, and having the whole incentive structure being revised and reviewed, has certainly borne much fruit. And as I say, with 51% market share, coming up from one stage where I think about 45 or 46, I think is testimony to that.

Of course, ARPU has declined unexpectedly. I still do think that if you look at Nigeria over the last five years, at a ARPU of I think about $11, it's still much, much stronger than any of us would have anticipated. Marginal ARPU is now down to $7 in Nigeria, and of course, we've had the interconnect decline by a few naira.

I think all in all, operation has gone very well. SIM registration similar to South Africa. Not as cumbersome, in terms of things that have to be fulfilled. But suffice to say that this SIM registration requirement is something that has taken off in virtually all the operations.

Coming back to Nigeria, 3G rollouts, we have done almost 300 sites. And I must say the smart phone end in Nigeria has taken off. I don't remember exactly how many BlackBerries now, but I think over 35,000 or something like that. So we're finding that because of the poor fixed-line connectivity, I think in the fullness of time, the 3G roll-out in Nigeria and the take-up in data in the high-end of the market will justify that.
We continue to provide a lot of self-provide on transmission. We've done almost another 700 kilometers, and we have also launched WiMAX in three states.

I think the important point here is, as we indicated, we thought 2009 would be the peak year in CapEx for the Group. Nigeria is obviously representative of that, in some respects. And you can see, compared to the comparative period last year, we're almost at half the CapEx. And we certainly believe that we'll maintain that for the rest of the year.

South Africa, we had a very rough patch last six months to December '09. I'm glad to say that things have turned around and things have picked up. Our market share is 36%. We'd be more comfortable with two points above that.

And of course, RICA, which was a challenge – I think it was a learning curve for all of us, but we've certainly got into rhythm on that. We had the town stormers, which is a network that was invested in a few years, and those guys were converted, and they have helped us to RICA people, if you like. And that has really helped, particularly on the prepaid side.

The postpaid growth has not been strong. We have seen a lot of people utilizing the hybrid packages. In other words, migrating from postpaid into either lower packages of postpaid or the hybrid package. And I think this is really indicative of the fairly pressing economic conditions that are prevalent. And of course, we've also ensured much strict credit policy, just to ensure that our doubtful debts are kept at an acceptable level.
We did have billing- and IT-related problems in 2009, and I am glad to say that a lot of that has been stabilized, and we've got less challenges there, and so on.

And the campaigns that we were undertaking were also fairly well targeted, primarily because of the very comprehensive segmentation exercise that all operations now go through. And I think on prepaid, we've had that benefit.

Once more, we are seeing a decline in ARPU. On the postpaid sides, it's driven by what I mentioned earlier, which is people migrating to lower packages and utilizing more of the hybrid products, based on the affordability. And a lot of bundle usage, as well.

And of course, we – as you know, we've had long discussions with ICASA on the mobile termination rates. We're still going through that Chapter 10 process. We are debating the gradient of that slide path, and hopefully, we'll arrive at some meaningful arrangement on that. But suffice to say that the business has structured itself so as to accommodate the further cuts.

CapEx in South Africa, same story as Nigeria, and indeed, the entire group, which is we are off our peak and down to R1 billion for the first six months, as opposed to a comparative R3 billion last year. But all of this was not in vain. As I keep on saying, the quality of the network, the capacity, and so on, again, is a benefit that is starting to come through very, very clearly. We've also put up more 3G sites, and we now are almost at 50% – 48% of the population is covered with 3G.

Fiber deployment is something that we continue to do quite extensively. As soon as government allowed us to self-provide, as you know, in the last two year, three years, we've embarked on this with much effort, simply to try and ensure that our transmission costs over time decline. So over 440 kilometers of the long distant line has – is being deployed. And the 220-kilometer ring around the Gauteng area, that was completed.

One big feature of the SA results is the pick-up in data. And again, that would not have been possible without investing more in transmission, and of course, generating the right products. So we're quite happy to say that, in fact, we've surpassed the targets we had set for ourselves. Because you may remember, two, three years back, we had said we wanted to reach 12% or 13% of revenue in South Africa in data. We're now at 18%. We're almost 20%. Quite a lot of operators in far more literate societies and so on are at 25, 30%. So I think we seem to be – for the South African profile, we're certainly on the right path in that area.

Ghana, if we can talk about West Africa a little, Ghana has done exceptionally well. This is really a operation in a five-player market. Has maintained market share of 56%. And it's quite important to say that that would not have happened yet again without significant investment in CapEx, which gave us the capacity, gave us the quality, enabled us therefore to be highly competitive as far as the take-up of subs and the subscribers that – the products that we put out there, as well as the number of subscribers we could take.

Of course, we – one big feature of Ghana, as you may recall, was the devaluation of the cedi, the Ghanaian cedi. And we are happy to say that it looks like there is some stability now in that particular area. And hopefully, once Ghana gets into production on oil, hopefully, it will begin to strengthen.
Again, very much effective distribution. Same strategy we followed in Nigeria was effective in Ghana and has yielded results.

Ghana is not on its own in demanding SIM registration, and we commenced implementing that on the 1st of July. And I must say, I think, as a group, we've been on the learning curve on this. We had a challenge in Sudan where we were caught unaware, but I think after Iran, South Africa, Cameroon, and so on, we've clearly got into a rhythm in anticipating how we deal with SIM registration. Provided everybody plays by the rules, we think this is a competitive area that we would do well in. Or take advantage of – maybe I should put it that way.

Yeah. Ghana also has managed to roll off some 3G sites. I'm afraid here I can't say that CapEx has come down as much, but one has to put into context that it is a five-player market, and it was crucial that we get ahead of the game. Having started, of course, on what we regard – [audio disturbance] – I don't know whether that's a message about what I'm saying, so I will ignore it for now.

Okay, but data usage in Ghana is also fairly significant, and MobileMoney has also taken up, maybe not as well as Uganda and East Africa, but certainly this is something that we intend to pursue. And at 7% of revenue, we think this has done relatively well.
Iran has been very much a star performer in this group. They have effectively grown the subs by 16%. Significant growth in revenue. And again, I think Nazir will deal this in his section.

One theme that runs through all these results is that these operations, on a local currency basis, have done exceptionally well. And Iran is not – has not been an exception. I think revenue is most probably over 60% on a comparative period. But we have had a lot of promotions that have been target for various seasonal things that happened in Iran, and which is really a feature of that country. And of course, we've now got much wider electronic distribution through a lot of the local banks, and that has helped.

Even though we believe that this third operator will commence operations by the end of the year, or maybe let's say first quarter of next year, we think that with 44% market share in Iran, we have basically positioned ourselves in almost in an unassailable position. Not to say that we're complacent about it, but I think it does put us in a very strong position to deal with any of the third entrants.

So I mean there we are. Subscribers, almost 27 million. To put this in context, it's been a very fast growth. South Africa went almost 14, 15 years to get to 17 million subscribers. In Iran, really this has been achieved in 4 years. So I think it just shows you what the opportunity was in terms of the depth of the market and so on.

The rollout. Again, we continue to deploy quite significantly CapEx in Iran, but this does follow the feature of the Group, in the sense that we haven't invested as much as last year in the first six months. We do have certain challenges when it comes to sites, which has slowed down the rollout somewhat, and particularly in Northern Tehran and Esfahan and some places. Sites are very difficult to come by. I'm very confident that if we were able to get more sites, obviously it would create more capacity, and we'd see a much higher uplift of revenue in Iran. So this is something that we continuously look at doing.

We have also launched WiMAX. We don't have 3G in Iran. We've also launched WiMAX in certain parts of the country, and we believe that that will go a long way to helping our data revenue in Iran increase even more significantly. The 19% is impressive, but that does include SMS. So it will be significantly lower if you exclude SMS.

Syria. Syria, as you now is almost like a duopoly of sorts, in the sense that the market is controlled in terms of how fast we can move relative to our competitor. But still 45% market share, which has remained relatively stable. Again, segmentation of products here is a very important feature that has helped us. And also helped us to try and reduce churn by being far more educated about our various segments and what's actually happening in each segment.

The biggest issue in Syria was the BOT. As you know, it's not a normal license there. I'm happy to say that, in principle, we are on track to resolve this by year-end. We have engaged government, and I think in principle, there's now an acceptance that there will be a conversion. And we're hoping that by year-end, that will be done, and we can come and share with you more comprehensively the details of that. Suffice to say that I do think it's a positive development for that operation, because I do believe that once the BOT is out of the way, we would be far less – I wouldn't say restrained – but we would be in a position to invest more in capacity there, and therefore increase the penetration in a country whose per capita GDP should have a higher penetration than it has today. So I see that essentially as an opportunity.

Again, that CapEx reflects a number of things. Partly the issue of the BOT conundrum, in the sense that we couldn't invest significantly until we get clarity as to where we're going forward on all of that. But the quality has remained quite acceptable. We have started very limited 3G service, and of course, are launching a lot of data products. At 10%, we really do think that there is still significant opportunity there.

So I think, in a nutshell, looking at things operationally and trying to give you a strategic overview, I know there has been perpetual questions about our business model and where we're going. Is the trajectory right, and so on. And of course, people are quite entitled to ask those questions. And I guess it's our task to answer those questions. But I do think that the strategy that we have followed thus far it has worked.

Let me start off by saying bulk of the growth has been organic growth in this company, notwithstanding some M&A that we've undertaken. But the bulk of the growth has been organic. We then invested significantly in CapEx. I mean, if you recall, starting in 2007, we invested significant amount of CapEx in fairly difficult jurisdictions at 35, R40 billion a year, that was, by any stretch of the imagination, significant CapEx. But what that has really precipitated for us or enabled us to do is to have, as I mentioned earlier, the network and the capacity. So today, with 51% market share in Nigeria, 56% in Ghana, and 66% in Uganda, and so on, is precisely because of the view that we took a few years – that we should actually create that capacity.

And the cost efficiencies, we spoke a lot about the low cost operator. And not to say that's a one-off. That's a process, which we continue. And there are lot of things that we haven't spoken about this morning, because I guess we don't have all the time, that we are doing to further try to ensure that we are on the downward trajectory as far as that cost base is concerned.

All of that has really resulted in fairly significant cash generation, not to mention the extremely low gearing. And we're able to pay the maiden dividend, that's almost R3 billion, for six months, as a result of having followed that strategy. And for us that is, of course, a way of ensuring that our ultimate task of shareholder returns is achieved.

Having said all of that, of course, we will continue to look at where opportunities are. I think what we said during the AGM is that, whilst we realize that there are now – there are far limited significant opportunities that are out there, we think that we cannot be inactive, because the terrain is changing all the time. I mean I spoke about consolidation, whether it's on a regional basis and so on.
So that is something that we will continue to do, but we hope to increase the balance in terms of particularly cash generation. Returning that to shareholders to reflect where the company is today.
So I think in short, that is the formula. That is the framework. And unless something absolutely radical happens, that's what we intend to maintain. Thank you very much.

Good morning, all. Members of the audience, especially we have to welcome the members of the Group Board, the members of the MTN Executive Committee, and also to members of the South Africa Board, as well. Thank you all for taking the time and the interest to participate in the session.
It gives me pleasure to present the Group's financial results. And I think Phuthuma's last slide provides an ideal opening for us to discuss the financial performance of the Group.

I mean to a large extent, we would like to believe that the first six months of this year are characterized by some key elements, which in terms of that particular framework, which we believe is to provide some steps in terms of our success in achieving those objectives. And the cash generation that he talked about is a clearly major step towards that.

One of the highlights, however, that Phuthuma alluded to earlier in his presentation was the ZAR strength in the first half of this year. If you recall, the first half results in 2009 were characterized by very weak ZAR performance, and the average ZAR rate to the dollar was in the order of just slightly above 9. I have a slide later in this presentation, which some of you might have seen already – it will explore that or explain that a bit further. We have seen that in the first six months of this year, the ZAR has been relatively strong against most other currencies, including the dollar, and that has a fairly dampening impact on the Group reported results for the first year.

What's very pleasing – we talked about the higher margins earlier in Phuthuma's presentation from South Africa and Iran, and we'll explain those in a bit more detail as we go through the presentation. But we've also lifted up. Despite the fact it's only five-tenths of a point of margin improvement, from 42.8% to 43.3% on a half-year, half-year basis, we did lift up margins overall for the Group in the last six months, from December '09 to now, by more than a full 2 percentage points.

So that's been very pleasing to see. I guess it's a challenge to operational management is to ensure that we find a way to keep those margins on that level, even towards the end of the year, as well. I'm looking at my South African friends across in the corner here to make sure they don't disappoint on that front. They have however showed me that they are in a good roll, so let's hope that comes through, as well.

Functional currency. I think in the past we've talked a lot about this. We've done some capital restructuring in the Group, and hopefully we've taken away some of that pain, but we are still exposed to some ForEx losses, and we'll talk about those as we go forward.

All of this translates – the margin improvement, the lower cap ex spend, a good conservation of cash flow – has helped us to drive free cash flow up from 2.6 billion at the end of the first six months in '09 to about 6.8 billion in the first six months in 2010. For purposes of this particular presentation, free cash flow is defined as cash generated by operations, which includes working capital changes, after payment of taxes, dividends, et cetera, and CapEx. So that's the way we tend to define it for this purpose.

HEPS, as a result, with a strong earnings base, HEPS increased by 20.6%, but keeping in mind, of course, that we did not take some of the big pain, I guess, on the reversing a credit from the put option that we saw in the first six months of 2009.

Moving on, we talked about fairly stable economic and trading conditions, but we still believe that in some cases, they might be relatively unpredictable. But a key feature, I think, in almost every one of our markets that we're operating in, is a fair amount of competition. And we see a lot of discounting on tariffs, and it's not uncharacteristic to see tariffs go down by 50%, and these are daily calls. We also see a lot of freebies being thrown around – bonus recharges, free night calling, et cetera, and we believe this is the order of the day. And I think to that extent, keeping that in mind, the results are actually pretty strong and very positive in terms of the way we performed.

We've seen strong subscriber growth. As Phuthuma pointed out, we've had a good subscriber intake of just over 11% in the first six months of the year. But we do have to keep in mind that this is now coming at declining marginal ARPUs. And that's something that we need to manage very efficiently. For the core framework that we put out there, the way we get increased margin is slower revenue generation in the future, but increased focus in terms of cost efficiency to generate more cash as we go forward.
Strong data growth, as has been pointed out, particularly in South Africa, but in the same time, we need to manage declining access pricing as we go forward.
On the FX side, not to talk too much about those. We've dealt with that and I think in as much detail as we need to.

However, on the regulatory front, probably a couple of points that are worth mentioning. Subscriber registration, as Phuthuma pointed out, has been initiated in a number of markets. I think we keep a watchful eye out on that. We've seen the impact it's had on South Africa. In Nigeria, we are now registering, as we indicated from the beginning of May, in accordance with – in compliance with government or regulatory regulations – registration of new subscribers.

The parameters for the registration of the existing base have not yet been defined. Needless to say, we have started a process of registration, we put a lot of equipment out in the field. We've done – trained a lot of people, and we've registered about a million people in Nigeria already. But that's something that we need to watch and keep an eye out going forward, because it have might have an impact on gross connections that we're seeing in other markets.

We are heavily involved in that process in Ghana. Made very good strides, I believe, in Cameroon, where we registered about 70% of the base. And we are also in process of registering the base in Ivory Coast. So this is something that's here to stay, and I think we'll see almost across the entire footprint.

From the accounting perspective , a few things that we need to keep in mind when looking at the results. Our Zambian shareholding has been reduced as part of a private placement arrangement, and that was in order to comply with the license conditions.

We reduced our Afghanistan share holding from 100% to just over 90%, and that's in accordance with a financing agreement in which a minority shareholder has a put option on us. We still account for about 100% of that from a consolidation perspective.

The put option – and this is a put option that most of you are familiar with. If you recall, in the last year, as a result primarily due to the devaluation of the naira against both the dollar and the ZAR, we took a fairly large credit to the income statement. The naira has remained fairly stable over the last six months, so in terms of updating the liability under that put option, we've now taken a slight charge. And that reflects clearly the softening of, I guess, the WAC rates associated with that particular country as well as the stability in terms of the cash flows that are coming through.

On the tax side, a higher tax charge than we expected. Some of it is related – and this is fairly consistent as far as the first three bullets are concerned. The STC on the Group dividends, the withholding tax and education tax – those effects that we would have seen in the prior year, as well, in terms of taking the blended statutory rate up to a higher number. But the other impact that we've had this year is as a result of the put option moving from a credit to debit, we have lower taxable income, and therefore a higher effective tax rate, even though the charges matched the overall revenue base or the income base.

Just to give a bit more color to the movement in exchange rates – and these are average exchange rates, and therefore have a fairly big impact on two items. One is in all your income statement based items, and secondly as well on your CapEx, as well. So the two shaded areas are the ones we need to focus on.

As we mentioned, it's more ZAR strength as opposed to underlying currency weakness in the operating countries that has added impact on the numbers. If you look at each one of the real, the naira, or the cedi, they have remained relatively stable against the dollar. There are slight movements, but not significant.

However, the rand moving from an average of 9.06 to 7.52 obviously means that the ZAR-reported results have been quite heavily impacted on a translation basis. So the cross-rates effectively against the rand have deteriorated somewhere between 16 to 26%, if you do it on a line-by-line basis. And therein really lies the problem or the headwinds that Phuthuma alluded to earlier.

On the revenue side, again underlying message was on the bottom right-hand corner, on a local currency basis, all operations seems to be performing relatively well. Nigeria, we see slower growth because of the decline in margin and ARPUs of around just below 15%. If you recall, in the first half of last year, those might have been slightly higher compared to 2008.

Iran, very, very strong at about 42%, largely associated with the fact that there was a slight uplift in local currency ARPUs, as well as a stable overall ARPUs of the existing base. So about a 42% increase.
Ghana and Uganda, very pleasing to see the rates that are coming through, despite a significant pressure on ARPUs, coming in much lower than we have seen in the past.

Looking at EBITDA performance, largely, again, keeping in mind the FX impacts. If we restated current year EBITDA at prior constant-currency rates, we would see about a R4.3 billion improvement on EBITDA or reported EBITDA or about 16.3%.

Nigeria margins have remained roughly steady at about 61%, despite a surge in fuel costs, which are quite a key driver of their OpEx. But generally, all of the costs have remained under control, so we've been able to deliver economies of scale in the operation.

On the RSA side, we've been able to keep handset revenues roughly stable, but we've been able to actually decrease the cost of the handsets to offset some of the revenue stabilization. So the overall margin on handsets has contributed to an uplift in the margins for the company overall.

I don't believe we'll see any short-term improvement in cost, but hopefully will give us some good news in 2011.

Now, what's happened between last year and this year, we lifted margins by more than 6 percentage points, is primarily very, very good cost control and a very good and efficient operating business model. Transmission costs have been reduced by more than 6%, although the overall quantum of cost is increased with the increase in the size of the network.

They've also moved to a single vendor maintenance program, and that to a large extent has helped to actually reduce the cost of the vendor maintenance or network maintenance on a year-on-year basis, despite the fact that we have a significant increase in the number of sites. They've also managed to actually reduce the cost of recharge cards, et cetera through very efficient procurement programs. And the advertising spend between the first half of last year and the first half of this year has also decreased.
All of that has contributed this – to very good cost management, increase in the margin, but at the same time, very strong revenue growth.

So overall for the Group, the EBITDA margin – here we go again. Reconciliation. Not much to speak of. We've talked about the Iran and RSA contributions. Other opco is just to point out something there: Sudan, Ghana and Côte d'Ivoire have all declined.

Ghana, the OpEx in Ghana is largely influenced by costs which are actually denominated – even though they might be paid in cedi, they're actually denominated in U.S. dollars. Okay. All right. Look, I think on MobileMoney, the question was, well, why would West Africa lag East Africa? There is no obvious reason other than the fact that, in credit to them, Safaricom started this with M-PESA, mobile money in Kenya. And again, credit to them. Many, many years before a lot of other operators started that. And I think that has taken off very, very well.

In Kenya, it's very established, and of course, as you know, the East African region is fairly integrated. And I think that has – there's quite a lot of movement between Uganda, Kenya and Tanzania and so on. So I think they've seen that benefit. It's a issue of familiarity, where that region is far more comfortable with MobileMoney, have used it used it quite a lot, starting in Kenya.
And of course, we launched in Uganda – let's say before the other countries, right? In our Group, we launched in Uganda way before other countries.

So that is really – for those two reasons, that's really why East Africa has done fairly well. But there is absolutely no reason, once the people feel far more familiar and far more comfortable with the product, why it shouldn't spread in West Africa, as well. I mean, it's like ATMs. When people used to go to ATMs, they'd still rather go into the branch. But today, everybody doesn't want to go into the branch, they just use the ATM. So it's the same sort of mentality.

The issue of – second question was about Bharti and cutting tariffs in Kenya. Well, first of all, we're not in Kenya. That was meant on a serious note. But having said that, I think the feature of the question really is, clearly, are these guys going to start cutting prices? And I think the specific question was, well, what does it mean for Nigeria? And some of you may recall that we had, I think, two very big scares in Nigeria in the past. When we went out with a new product that took down tariffs, because of the high elasticity of that market, we'd then get an enormous growth in traffic. And when you get that enormous growth in the traffic, clearly, you must then have the network and the capacity to do that.

So it's not for us to comment on other people's strategies and what they will do and what they won't do. But I think my response – I'll just leave you with a response that says, if you're going to go and have significant cuts in tariffs, you need the capacity. Particularly in a country like Nigeria, you absolutely need the capacity, because if you don't have the capacity, you'd be in very dire straits as far as the network is concerned.
So I think that's the first response. Second response is, of course, no tariffs, enormous volumes works; low tariff, not such enormous volumes has got its own challenges on revenue.
Sifiso, you want to comment on Sudan?
Just on Sudan, we had to, let's say, disconnect 600,000 subscribers that were actually not active. So that had no impact on the revenue at all.

As far as turning around the business is concerned, we've just had difficulties in relation to getting the rollout in place. And earlier on there was a mention of that, we did have some significant management changes. And I think that we're now on a good note to actually get it going well.
